issue.title: Create a way to visualize joint limits

content.raw: This could be straight-forward for the prismatic joint, since it is just a translation along the axis. It is harder for rotational joints that allow more than 360 degrees of rotation (for example a steering wheel that can turn 3 or 4 times before hitting the limits).
content.html: This could be straight-forward for the prismatic joint, since it is just a translation along the axis. It is harder for rotational joints that allow more than 360 degrees of rotation (for example a steering wheel that can turn 3 or 4 times before hitting the limits).

issue.title: Create a way to visualize joint limits

content.raw:
Something to consider is using a GUI overlay object or a pop-up window instead of showing limits in the 3D world. For example, a window could list each joint (let you choose a joint) and then show the joint limits as numbers.

If you want something in the 3D space, it might be good to have the visual only appear when the user hovers over the joint's axis. Otherwise the screen may be too cluttered. You can put text in 3D space. For a revolute joint you could have an arc around the axis of rotation labeled with start and stop positions. A revolute joint with a rotation of > 360 could have the start and stop at the same location with appropriate labels.

There are quite a few joints to consider (such as a gear joints, universal, hinge2). The 2D pop-up window will be easier, but not as cool.
content.html:
Something to consider is using a GUI overlay object or a pop-up window instead of showing limits in the 3D world. For example, a window could list each joint (let you choose a joint) and then show the joint limits as numbers.

If you want something in the 3D space, it might be good to have the visual only appear when the user hovers over the joint's axis. Otherwise the screen may be too cluttered. You can put text in 3D space. For a revolute joint you could have an arc around the axis of rotation labeled with start and stop positions. A revolute joint with a rotation of > 360 could have the start and stop at the same location with appropriate labels.

There are quite a few joints to consider (such as a gear joints, universal, hinge2). The 2D pop-up window will be easier, but not as cool.

issue.title: Create a way to visualize joint limits

content.raw:
I think displaying the limits as numbers is already covered in the main window (model list widget) and in the model editor (joint inspector).

I agree that showing something in the 3D space for all joints at the same time would clutter the screen. I like the idea of only showing it on hover, and perhaps also for the selected joint.
content.html:
I think displaying the limits as numbers is already covered in the main window (model list widget) and in the model editor (joint inspector).

I agree that showing something in the 3D space for all joints at the same time would clutter the screen. I like the idea of only showing it on hover, and perhaps also for the selected joint.

issue.title: Create a way to visualize joint limits

content.raw: We could visualize it by rendering the model with the joints at max and min limits, or an animation cycling between the two.
content.html: We could visualize it by rendering the model with the joints at max and min limits, or an animation cycling between the two.

issue.title: Create a way to visualize joint limits

content.raw:
That would be nice. Something like?

1. Show the link as transparent (or some other way that makes it visually distinct)
1. Animate the link through it's range of motion (hot keys or a gui buttons could snap the link to min or max positions, and potentially step through the animation)
content.html:
That would be nice. Something like?

  1. Show the link as transparent (or some other way that makes it visually distinct)
  2. Animate the link through it's range of motion (hot keys or a gui buttons could snap the link to min or max positions, and potentially step through the animation)

issue.title: Create a way to visualize joint limits

content.raw: Yeah, that's what I was thinking. It would be intuitive to see the actual motion.
content.html: Yeah, that's what I was thinking. It would be intuitive to see the actual motion.
